_prev_prog_3.Description: Butter, margaine, oil and lard processing. Soybean and other oils processed with flavorings to manufacture a variety of margarine, toppings and spreads. Shortening, blend and lard processing and packaging are also conducted on site.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary



Ventura Foods LLC

Albert Lea, MN





The following subsections outline the Executive Summary requirements of the EPA's 40 CFR Part 68.155.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



The Ventura Foods, Albert Lea facility abides by the emergency response procedures and policies detailed in the Emergency Response Plan.  This Plan was designed to meet the following objectives:



1.    To operate safely and avoid injuries

2.    To protect the environment

3.    To minimize property damage

4.    To meet regulatory requirements

5.    To educate our employees





Ventura Foods maintains an ammonia safety and risk assessment team whose members are the designated emergency coordinators for the facility.  The Plan provides the organization and notification procedures, evacuation routes, ammonia health hazards, and mitigation procedures which will be implemented to respond effectively to emergency situations that may arise at the facility.  This plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year to ensure compliance with the PSM and RMP regulations, as well as to incorporate any facility changes. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Ventura Foods is located on the south end of the community, in the City of Albert Lea, Minnesota. The facility processes vegetable and animal oils used in the production of high-quality margarine, spreads, cooking oil and lard products. The means of cooling, required in the production phase of our products, is the closed loop anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system with an operating charge of 13,220 lbs. and a maximum intended inventory (not to exceed) of 16,800 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia. 



 

The RMP requires facilities handling threshold amounts of anhydrous ammonia to submit Plans for the prevention of accidental releases of these substances.  The submission includes hazard assessments and release scenarios defining possible off-site impacts of the regulated substance. A fiv

e-year accident history,a description of the facilities accidental release prevention program, and an emergency response program are also included. 





GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The ammonia refrigeration system is subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management, 29 CFR 1910.119 and the EPA's Risk Management rule for a Level 3 process.  The OSHA Process Safety Management / EPA Prevention Program consists of facility management policies and procedures that promote and recognize ammonia safety and the prevention of accidents in plants that handle, use, store, or process hazardous chemical materials. 



The plant has written policies and procedures addressing all aspects of Process Safety Management and EPA Prevention Programs. To help maintain technical expertise and RAGAGEP standards, Ventura Foods, LLC maintains membership in IIAR and uses their technical bulletins as one basis for evaluating process activities. 





5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Ventura Foods, LLC Albert Lea facility has had no accidental releases in the past five years.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The plant has a written Emergency Response Plan in effect.  Ventura Foods, LLC. is committed to responding and mitigating any accidental releases to minimize the impact to employees, the community, and our environment.  The response plan is coordinated with the Emergency Response Agencies, Albert Lea Fire Department & Freeborn County LEPC. The plant has interacted with the designated responding agencies for many years regarding the plan and activities involved.  



Employees are trained in the implementation of the plan and in possible response activities that could be required in the event of an emergency.  The plant has developed a Hazmat Team made up of plant employees who are trained to respond in the event of an ammonia release on site.



PLANNED CHANGES to IMPROVE SAFETY

Safety improvements are a continual and ongoing process at the plant, facilitated by the EPA Prevention

Program and OSHA's Process Safety Management Program.  Formal process hazard analysis is conducted at least every five years, but review is constant through management of change procedures, operator training, incident investigation, and mechanical integrity programs. 

 

Ventura Foods has partnered with third party contractors to deliver Process Safety Management & Risk Management training and audit support. As a result, our programs and employees benefit from the current industry information.
